skill.name: systematic-debugging
skill.description:
Systematic methodology for debugging bugs, test failures, and unexpected behavior.
Use when encountering any technical issue before proposing fixes. Covers root cause
investigation, pattern analysis, hypothesis testing, and fix implementation.
Use ESPECIALLY when under time pressure, "just one quick fix" seems obvious, or
you've already tried multiple fixes. NOT for exploratory code reading.

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no code execution capabilities. Verification script only reads files for structural validation. No network, filesystem beyond skill directory, or external command execution detected.

content.value_statement: Random fixes waste time and create new bugs. This skill enforces a four-phase debugging process that always finds root cause before proposing fixes, preventing symptom-level patches and architectural debt.
actual_capabilities: Enforces root cause investigation before any fix attempts
Guides through four-phase debugging: investigation, pattern analysis, hypothesis testing, implementation
Provides backward tracing technique for locating bug origins
Identifies when architectural problems require discussion instead of patches
limitations: Does not execute code or run tests directly
Does not access external debugging tools or profilers
Does not modify files or make automated fixes
Requires user to provide access to code and error messages

use_cases.title: Fix recurring bugs properly
use_cases.description: Stop patching symptoms. Trace bugs to their source using backward tracing through the call stack.

use_cases.title: Debug test failures systematically
use_cases.description: Reproduce failures consistently and identify root causes before proposing test modifications.

use_cases.title: Apply structured debugging to any issue
use_cases.description: Follow the Iron Law: no fixes without root cause investigation. Works with any codebase.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Issue
prompt_templates.prompt: Use systematic-debugging. Issue: [describe the bug or error]

prompt_templates.title: Test Failure
prompt_templates.prompt: Use systematic-debugging. Test [test name] is failing with: [error message and stack trace]

prompt_templates.title: Architectural Problem
prompt_templates.prompt: Use systematic-debugging. We have tried [number] fixes already and none worked. [describe the issue and what was attempted]

output_examples.input: Use systematic-debugging. The CI build is failing with 'git init failed in /Users/jesse/project/packages/core'
output: Phase 1 - Root Cause Investigation: Tracing the git init error backward through the call chain
Phase 2 - Pattern Analysis: Comparing against working git operations in the codebase
Phase 3 - Hypothesis: Testing one variable at a time to isolate the cause
Phase 4 - Implementation: Creating a failing test case and implementing fix at the source
Defense-in-depth: Adding validation at each layer to make the bug structurally impossible

best_practices: Always complete Phase 1 (root cause investigation) before attempting any fix
Test one hypothesis at a time and verify before moving on
After three failed fix attempts, stop and question the architecture with the user
anti_patterns: Proposing fixes before tracing data flow to find the source
Making multiple changes at once to 'see what works'
Assuming the first obvious cause is the root cause

faq.question: What AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Compatible with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. Works with any LLM that supports skill prompts.

faq.question: How long does the debugging process take?
faq.answer: For simple bugs, Phase 1 takes seconds. Complex issues may require multiple iterations. Systematic debugging is faster than guess-and-check thrashing.

faq.question: Can I skip phases under time pressure?
faq.answer: No. The Iron Law enforces all four phases. Skipping investigation leads to symptom fixes that create new bugs.

faq.question: What data does this skill access?
faq.answer: No code execution or file access. It provides methodology guidance. You provide code and error context in your prompts.

faq.question: How does this handle multi-component systems?
faq.answer: Phase 1 includes gathering evidence at each component boundary: log data entering and exiting, verify config propagation.

faq.question: How is this different from other debugging skills?
faq.answer: Enforces the Iron Law (no fixes without root cause) and the three-fix limit (stop and discuss architecture after three failed attempts).
